messages.content: change mac iphone backup to harddrive

To change your Mac's iPhone backup location to an external hard drive, follow these steps carefully. We'll create a **symlink (symbolic link)** so that iTunes or Finder thinks it's backing up to the original folder, but the data will actually be stored on your external drive.

---

### ðŸ” Step-by-Step Guide

#### 1. **Locate the Current Backup Folder**
In Finder, press `Cmd + Shift + G` and go to:
```
~/Library/Application Support/MobileSync/
```
Inside, you'll see a folder named `Backup`.

#### 2. **Move the Backup Folder to Your External Hard Drive**
Letâ€™s say your external hard drive is named `MyExternalHD`.

- Copy the `Backup` folder to:
```
/Volumes/MyExternalHD/iPhoneBackup/
```
So you'll have:
```
/Volumes/MyExternalHD/iPhoneBackup/Backup
```

#### 3. **Rename the Original Backup Folder**
Go back to:
```
~/Library/Application Support/MobileSync/
```
Rename `Backup` to `Backup-old` (just in case something goes wrong).

#### 4. **Create a Symlink**
Open Terminal and paste this command:
```bash
ln -s /Volumes/MyExternalHD/iPhoneBackup/Backup ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup
```

âœ”ï¸ This creates a symbolic link that redirects all backups to your external drive.

#### 5. **Test the Backup**
- Connect your iPhone.
- Use Finder (macOS Catalina and later) or iTunes (pre-Catalina).
- Run a backup and confirm that new files appear in the external driveâ€™s `Backup` folder.

---

### ðŸ”„ To Revert Back

If you ever want to go back:

```bash
rm ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup
mv ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup-old ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup
```

---

### ðŸ” Redirect iPhone Backup to External Drive (No Existing Backup)

#### ðŸ§­ Step 1: Create the Backup Folder on Your External Drive

Letâ€™s say your external drive is called `MyExternalHD`.

- Open Finder and go to:
  ```
  /Volumes/MyExternalHD/
  ```
- Create a new folder (e.g., `iPhoneBackup`)
- Inside that folder, create another folder called `Backup`, so the full path is:
  ```

  ```

---

#### ðŸ’¥ Step 2: Create a Symbolic Link

Open Terminal and paste the following (adjust the drive name if different):

```bash
ln -s /Volumes/MyExternalHD/iPhoneBackup/Backup ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup
```

This tells macOS:  
âž¡ï¸ â€œWhenever an app tries to write a backup to the default location, actually write it to the external drive.â€

---

#### ðŸ“² Step 3: Backup Your iPhone

- Plug in your iPhone
- Open **Finder** (on macOS Catalina and later) or **iTunes** (on Mojave and earlier)
- Initiate a manual backup
- Your backup will now be written to the external drive!

---

### âœ… Confirm It Worked

You can check the contents of this folder:
```

```
You should see a long cryptic folder name appear â€” thatâ€™s your backup.

Ah yes â€” this is a **quirk** of how iPhone backups work on macOS. Even **with a symbolic link**, macOS *still checks your internal driveâ€™s free space* before starting the backup â€” **even if the actual backup will be stored externally**.

---

### ðŸ§  Why This Happens

Finder/iTunes:
- First checks internal disk space
- Then starts writing data (follows symlink to external drive)
  
So: âœ… storage *used* = external drive  
But: âŒ storage *checked* = internal drive

---

### ðŸ› ï¸ Solutions

#### Option 1: **Free up enough space on your internal drive just to pass the check**
Youâ€™ll need at least **10â€“20 GB free**, depending on your iPhone size.

You can:
- Delete old iPhone backups:  
  ```bash
  rm -rf ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup-old
  ```
- Clear cached files:
  ```bash
  ~/Library/Caches
  /private/var/folders/
  ```
  (Use a tool like [CleanMyMac](https://macpaw.com/cleanmymac) or `Finder > Go to Folder...`)

---

#### Option 2: **Use third-party backup software**  
Apps like [iMazing](https://imazing.com/) **donâ€™t check internal drive space** and let you **choose your backup location directly**, including external drives.

- Pros:
  - No symlinks
  - Choose backup path freely
- Cons:
  - Paid (though free trial often lets you back up once)

---

#### Option 3: **Temporarily trick macOS using a sparse image (advanced)**  
This involves mounting a virtual disk image stored on your external drive and linking to that. More complex, but it can bypass the space check entirely.

I can walk you through this if you're interested â€” itâ€™s like creating a virtual drive that lives on your external one.

---

### ðŸ‘‰ Recommended Next Step

- Try freeing up 20 GB on your internal drive **just to pass the check**.
- Then do the backup â€” all the data will go to the external.
